Identifying Characteristics: Typical trout-shaped body covered with light spots on a darker background of green or grayish brown
Closely related to the Brook Trout, but lack the bright coloration and can be distinguished by a deeply forked tail
Biology: Spawn in the fall during the period from mid-October (northern Maine) to mid-November (southern Maine); as surface water temperatures cool below 60o F
Mature fish typically congregate near exposed, shallow shoals or rocky shorelines
Males defend their chosen territories against the intrusion of rival males prior to active spawning
Spawning occurs at night, at depths usually less than six feet, and sometimes only a few inches
Eggs are broadcast over the bottom where they settle and become sheltered in the crevices among the rocks
Size: Largest freshwater game fish. Average size is 18 to 24 inches and 2 to 4 pounds, but may attain grow to greater than 30 inches in length and 10 pounds
Long-lived species often living 20 years or more
Diet: Fish, prefer smelt if they are present
Habitat: Typical habitat is large, deep, coldwater lakes with irregular bottom contours and rocky shorelines
May be found in rivers, stream and shallow lakes
Range: Native Range: northern New England, the Great Lakes, New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Minnesota, Montana, Idaho, and Alaska and Canada.
